author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Jeff Chen takes a turn playing the heroic role of acrostic constructor.
content: ACROSTIC — First-time readers of this column may be unfamiliar with Jeff Chen, a longtime constructor of crossword puzzles who, with Jim Horne, runs XWordInfo.com. This is his first crack at an acrostic for The New York Times. No surprise that it’s a wonderful solve; it’s challenging enough to be satisfying but doable in one sitting. It’s also a great example of the genre for someone who is interested but hasn’t yet been hooked on acrostics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: The Beauty of a One-Bedroom House? No Room for Guests.
description: When two designers created their own country retreat, they knew they wanted the opposite of what most of their clients ask for: Something tiny.
content: As the founders of Haver & Skolnick Architects, an upscale firm based in Roxbury, Conn., Charles M. Haver and Stewart R. Skolnick spend most of their days designing expansive country estates. But when it came time to design their own getaway, they wanted the exact opposite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Four Freedoms, According to Republicans
description: This is not what Franklin Roosevelt had in mind.
content: On Tuesday, Republicans in North Carolina overrode Gov. Roy Cooper’s veto to pass a strict limit on bodily autonomy in the form of a 12-week abortion ban.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Adventure and Independence Await. Bug Spray Sold Separately.
description: Seven brand-new and time-tested books about sleepaway camp.
content: Ghost stories and s’mores. Friendship bracelets and three-legged races. Trail mix, canoe trips, stars visible from a cozy bunk. For some kids who’ve been lucky enough to belt out “99 Bottles of Beer on the Wall” on a bus bound for the middle of nowhere, these are the touchstones of a place that becomes the center of everything — a backdrop for little lessons and big mileposts, a haven to return to year after year. For others, sleepaway camp is a hellscape of mystery meat, mean counselors, itchy sunburn, belly flops and kickballs to the gut. Their letters are desperate pleas for compassionate release, with nary a mention of the stained glass workshop or floating trampoline that made the program attractive to begin with.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny’ Premieres at Cannes: First Reaction
description: After paying tribute to an emotional Harrison Ford, the festival unspooled the newest sequel to decidedly mixed results.
content: On Thursday, Harrison Ford stood before a rapturous crowd at the Cannes Film Festival and reminded us that Tom Cruise isn’t the last movie star.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: Office Workers Don’t Hate the Office. They Hate the Commute.
description: Don’t expect a race back to the workplace if it remains a hassle to get there.
content: Elon Musk says we should all get off our duffs and go back to the office. People who want to work from home aren’t just “phoning it in” from “some remote pseudo-office” as he’s put it in the past. Now he says we’re immoral, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: DeSantis Amps Up His Retail Campaign in New Hampshire
description: The Florida governor met with state lawmakers and made the standard diner visit to press flesh with voters, showcasing his more moderate side.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida on Friday hinted at how he might try to soften his image as a conservative hard-liner, a strategy that appeared intended to target more moderate voters in the state, which holds a centrist reputation and could be decisive in the Republican primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Tsunami Warnings Issued for Pacific Island Nations After Quake
description: After a 7.7 magnitude earthquake was recorded, a U.S. agency warned that waves as high as 10 feet could hit Vanuatu. But it later downgraded the estimate, and no major damage was reported.
content: A magnitude 7.7 earthquake struck the South Pacific on Friday, triggering tsunami warnings for a number of Pacific island nations. But hours later, no significant damage had been reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Haney and Lomachenko Give Lightweight Boxing a Stirring Matchup
description: Devin Haney is both a champion and an up-and-comer. Vasiliy Lomachenko is seeking a title again after a break to fight for Ukraine.
content: LAS VEGAS — Forty minutes into an April workout, Devin Haney, the undisputed lightweight champion, stalked across the ring at the Top Rank Gym to throw punches at a coach wearing target mitts, a thick body pad and, as the session continued, a grimace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller and Shane Goldmacher
title: With Feinstein Ailing, Newsom’s Vow Looms Over Senate Race
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California promised in 2021 that he would appoint a Black woman to replace Senator Dianne Feinstein if she were to resign early.
content: Two years ago, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California vowed on national television that if Senator Dianne Feinstein stepped down early, he would appoint a Black woman to replace her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oliver Whang
title: The Reason People Listen to Sad Songs
description: It’s not because they make us sad but because they help us feel connected, a new study suggests.
content: When Joshua Knobe was younger, he knew an indie rock musician who sang sorrowful, “heart-rending things that made people feel terrible,” he recalled recently. At one point he came across a YouTube video, set to her music, that had a suicidal motif. “That was the theme of her music,” he said, adding, “So I had this sense of puzzlement by it, because I also felt like it had this tremendous value.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Ukraine arrests a top judge as the country’s corruption scandal grows.
description: The chief of Ukraine’s Supreme Court was formally arrested on Thursday, as prosecutors indicated in a second day of hearings that a high-level corruption case was expanding to include a wider circle of judges.
content: The chief of Ukraine’s Supreme Court was formally arrested on Thursday, as prosecutors indicated in a second day of hearings that a high-level corruption case was expanding to include a wider circle of judges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Do Dress Sneakers Belong in the Oval Office?
description: People felt strongly after spotting the hybrid shoe at a meeting with the president.
content: Think of it as a rare instance of cross-aisle consensus or else a sartorial trend gone badly wrong. But it did not go unnoticed when, in a photograph from the Oval Office posted to President Joe Biden’s account this week, Speaker of the House Kevin McCarthy, Senator Mitch McConnell and Representative Hakeem Jeffries were all captured wearing some variant of the dreaded footwear hybrid: the sneaker shoe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Shermane Billingsley, Guardian of the Stork Club’s Legacy, Dies at 78
description: The nightspot her father opened as a Prohibition-era speakeasy endured as a Manhattan institution until 1965. For decades she was “the keeper of the flame.”
content: Shermane Billingsley was barely 2 years old when the Broadway gossip columnist Dorothy Kilgallen revealed that Shermane was bedridden with a fever of 104. Less than a year later, Walter Winchell reported that Shermane had vamped to an inquiring columnist, “I will break your heart someday with my big blue eyes!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: To See One of A.I.’s Greatest Dangers, Look to the Military
description: A.I. and nuclear weapons could make for a catastrophic combination.
content: Rogue artificial intelligence versus humankind is a common theme in science fiction. It could happen, I suppose. But a more imminent threat is human beings versus human beings, with A.I. used as a lethal weapon by both sides. That threat is growing rapidly because there is an international arms race in militarized A.I.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Superstar Billy Graham, Model of the Buff, Blond Wrestler, Dies at 79
description: His spectacular physique, outrageous personality and blond dye job inspired Hulk Hogan and Jesse Ventura. But the steroids that built his body also destroyed it.
content: Superstar Billy Graham, a professional wrestler whose extravagant presence — 22-inch biceps, dyed blond hair, feather boas, tie-dyed tights and an outrageous gift of gab — influenced the style of future stars like Hulk Hogan and Jesse Ventura, died on Wednesday in Phoenix. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Blur Surprises With a Reflection on Fame, and 9 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Bad Bunny, Sparks, Anohni and the Johnsons and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall and Alex Williams
title: Andy Rourke, Bassist for the Smiths, Dies at 59
description: His sinewy bass lines were a vital — if, as one writer put it, “habitually unsung” — part of the influential British rock band’s success.
content: Andy Rourke, the bass player who provided the muscle and drive behind the darkly poetic musings of the Smiths, one of the most influential bands of the 1980s, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 59.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Robbed of Joy, Ukraine’s Teens Laugh to Keep From Weeping
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, May 19, 2023.
content: “There’s nothing here. But I don’t want to leave.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Needelman and Sasha Arutyunova
title: Blacksmithing Is Alive and Well in Kentucky
description: The “functional art” of Craig Kaviar, including transforming guns into garden tools, is part of a revival of the ancient craft.
content: Art of Craft is a series about specialists whose work rises to the level of art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Sarah Kerr, Kassie Bracken and Nimet Kirac
title: Greece Says It Doesn’t Ditch Migrants at Sea. It Was Caught in the Act.
description: Video evidence shows asylum seekers, among them young children, being rounded up, taken to sea and abandoned on a raft by the Greek Coast Guard.
content: The asylum seekers had already hopscotched countries for years to escape war in the Horn of Africa. They had barely set foot in Europe, hoping to start new lives, when masked men rounded them up and stripped them of their belongings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Salman Rushdie Makes Surprise Appearance at PEN America Gala
description: The novelist, who was stabbed and gravely wounded at a literary event last year, received an award from the freedom of expression organization.
content: Salman Rushdie walked onstage at PEN America’s annual gala on Thursday night, his first public appearance since he was stabbed and gravely wounded in an attack last August at a literary event in Western New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: ‘Movie Theaters Are the Marketplace of Free Ideas’
description: John Fithian spent nearly three decades as the top lobbyist for movie theaters. He says their future is bright, despite the power of streaming.
content: John Fithian saw a lot during his nearly three decades as the president and chief executive of the National Association of Theater Owners, the top lobbyist for movie theaters, a tenure that ended on May 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Why Dianne Feinstein, Like Many Before Her, Refuses to Let Go
description: A life in Congress comes with power, prestige and perks that can be hard to leave behind. For some lawmakers who view their job as their identity, the prospect is unthinkable.
content: Former Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, has put on a suit nine times since 2014, when he retired after serving in Congress for 40 years. He counts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: What Rainn Wilson Learned Searching for Joy Around the World
description: In a new travel series, the actor explores the world’s happiest (and unhappiest) countries to try and unlock the secrets of well-being.
content: The actor Rainn Wilson, who is best known for playing Dwight Schrute on “The Office,” has been candid about his history with anxiety and depression. In 2008, he founded Soul Pancake, a digital media company that explores “life’s big questions” as part of his search for clarity. His struggle to find happiness has also led him to churn through therapists and self-help books.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Connolly
title: The Tyranny of ‘the Best’
description: In toasters and in life, the top-rated anything will never be good enough.
content: Let me tell you about my friend Dan Symons. There is a kind of person who finds the idea of seeking out “the best” incredibly enticing, on an almost spiritual level. The kind of person who genuinely enjoys perusing articles like “the nine best hair dryers of 2023,” who is overcome with clammy dread at the idea of drinking in a bar with only a four-star rating on Google, who, in order to plan a weekend getaway, requires a prolonged and extensive operation that involves several spreadsheets. You know the type. Maybe you even are the type.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: Cities vs. Rising Seas
description: Around the world, tens of millions could lose their homes in the coming decades. Planning is the key to protecting them.
content: What does a country do when rising seas threaten to swamp its coastal capital?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: Paparazzi Speak on Meghan and Harry’s Car Chase
description: Complicated dynamics between celebrities and the paparazzi contributed to the confusion around a recent incident in New York City.
content: “It’s a messed-up business,” said Roger Wong, a freelance photographer, who on Thursday evening was among a few dozen others waiting on a red carpet outside the Hard Rock Hotel, near Times Square. He was hoping to get a sellable shot of Martha Stewart, one of this year’s cover models for Sports Illustrated’s annual swimsuit issue. “But what am I going to do? Start flipping burgers? I’d probably make more money, but it’s not my thing.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: DeSantis Lawyers Ask Judge in Disney Case to Recuse Himself
description: They argued that Judge Mark E. Walker’s comments in two unrelated proceedings displayed a bias toward the company.
content: Lawyers for Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida asked a federal judge on Friday to step down from a case brought by Disney, saying his comments in two unrelated court proceedings last year displayed a bias toward the company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Entrada Kelly
title: Lost (and Found) at Sea and in Space
description: Marine biology and astronomy play crucial roles in two middle grade novels about trauma and mental health.
content: Middle grade literature has increasingly incorporated the natural world into its story lines, projecting home and school conflicts onto the greater landscape (and vice versa). “Julia and the Shark,” by Kiran Millwood Hargrave, and “Simon Sort of Says,” by Erin Bow, are two recent additions to this canon. Both books explore trauma and mental health, along with the usual travails of growing up, via gentle first-person narration, but the voices of their titular characters make for wholly different reading experiences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: ‘Yellowjackets’ Season 2, Episode 8 Recap: The Wilderness Gets Choosy
description: The Yellowjackets are outsourcing a lot of their decisions to “the wilderness” lately. Too bad for its latest victim.
content: Earlier this season on “Yellowjackets,” young Natalie recruited her teammates to help her try to fish a moose out of the frozen lake. The moose proved too heavy to dislodge, and it disappeared into the icy water, leaving the teens defeated and hungry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Ana Swanson
title: To Counter China, G7 Countries Borrow Its Economic Playbook
description: Wealthy democracies rev up an effort to spend trillions on a new climate-friendly energy economy, while stealing away some of China’s manufacturing power.
content: Midway through his face-to-face meeting with President Biden in Indonesia last fall, the Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, offered an unsolicited warning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Victoria Kim
title: With Prospect of F-16s Closer, Zelensky Will Attend the G7 Strengthened
description: The Ukrainian president’s attendance at the meeting comes after President Biden opened the door to other nations training Ukrainian pilots and sending their F-16s to Kyiv.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine will attend the Group of 7 summit in Hiroshima, Japan, this weekend, to seek further commitments for more arms and aid from the world’s wealthiest democracies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Rockets Sent Israelis Running From the Beach. A Rare Seal Brought Them Back.
description: The incongruous arrival of a large and endangered monk seal has distracted Israelis from a period of violence and political unrest.
content: Yulia the endangered seal did not seem fazed by the rockets from Gaza, let alone the missiles heading in the opposite direction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: When Leaders With Authoritarian Streaks Like Elections
description: Turkey and Thailand held two huge elections this week, both with uncertain outcomes. Each shows some of the benefits that elections can hold for leaders who have amassed power with the tools of the state.
content: Two important elections happened this week. In Turkey, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan failed to win an outright victory so he now faces a runoff election that could be the most significant political challenge of his career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Our TV critic recommends a documentary about the Hillsong megachurch and a top-shelf drama that never got its due.
content: ‘XO, Kitty’When to watch: Now, on Netflix.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kay Redfield Jamison
title: How a Psychologist Confronted Her Own Bipolar Disorder
description: When Kay Redfield Jamison, author of “Fires in the Dark,” had a manic episode early in her career, she had to face hard truths about her illness and life.
content: Dr. Daniel Auerbach, the chief resident in psychiatry at the University of California, Los Angeles, supervised my work on the adult ward in the late 1970s. I learned from his observations of my clinical practice and by watching him treat patients directly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: He Promised Change in Thailand. But Will He Be Allowed to Lead?
description: Pita Limjaroenrat led his party to victory in the Thai election and seems poised to become the next prime minister, unless the military blocks him.
content: When Pita Limjaroenrat was a student at Harvard in 2008, he shadowed his American classmates who were campaigning at the time for former President Barack Obama. The experience gave him a window into electoral politics, from phone banks and polling data to knocking on doors and putting campaign flags on front lawns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Happy Valley’ Review: The End of the Hero’s Journey
description: Sarah Lancashire returns in the long-delayed final season of one of the best, and most human, crime dramas on TV.
content: Each season of the great British series “Happy Valley” begins the same way, with the rock-solid cop Catherine Cawood (Sarah Lancashire) facing the everyday bizarrerie of policing in a tired, depressed, grimly beautiful pocket of West Yorkshire: teenage sheep rustlers, a jilted boyfriend threatening to set himself on fire, unseen agitators heaving kitchen appliances out of upper-story windows onto patrol cars. Compassionate but impatient and prone to anger, smarter than the detectives who condescend to her, Cawood wears her black uniform and neon vest like a bulky suit of armor. She’s a contemporary knight errant, upholding a code of decency against the terrors of modern life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Outdoor Dining in New York City Is Here to Stay. (Just Not in Winter.)
description: City officials intend to pass a law that formally allows roadway dining sheds, but with some design guidelines.
content: New York City’s outdoor dining program, a popular pandemic-era measure designed to be a temporary salve for a devastated restaurant industry, is about to become a permanent part of the city’s landscape.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Rational Approaches to Immigration
description: Readers offer suggestions on U.S. policy. Also: The debt negotiations; Senator Dianne Feinstein; urban exodus; aid workers in Sudan.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: Review: A ‘Brokeback Mountain’ Lacking Some Intensity
description: A new West End adaptation, starring Lucas Hedges and Mike Faist, recasts Annie Proulx’s 1997 short story as a memory play.
content: “This ain’t no little thing,” Jack Twist (Mike Faist) says of the depth of attraction he is experiencing in “Brokeback Mountain.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Warren Zanes
title: What We Can Learn From Bruce Springsteen’s Great Left Turn
description: When music gets cleaned up too much, listeners lose opportunities to connect their imperfections with those in the music.
content: I was in the car with my sons, listening to the Beach Boys. I picked some of my favorite songs: “Wendy,” “Girl Don’t Tell Me,” “Let Him Run Wild.” But when I played another track I love, “Wild Honey,” the boys cocked their heads. “Why did they put that out?” one of them asked. The lead vocal sounded wrong to him. Fair enough. Something was off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna and CC Allen
title: How One of New York’s Last Bagel Masters Rolls Thousands by Hand
description: For the YouTube series “On the Job,” Priya Krishna spent a day with Celestino García, who works his magic at three New York shops.
content: Without Celestino García, New Yorkers might go without some of their most beloved bagels. At well-known shops like Court Street Bagels and Tompkins Square Bagels, you can see long lines out the door most mornings — but Mr. García’s work there is less visible. From 2 a.m. until late in the afternoon, he’s in the kitchen, mixing and hand-rolling dough in all kinds of flavors. Bagels can now be made by machine, so there aren’t many masters of the form left who can roll them by hand. But many bagel enthusiasts swear by the handmade approach, insisting that it produces a fluffier, chewier bite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Jim Brown, Football Great and Civil Rights Champion, Dies at 87
description: After a Hall of Fame career in the N.F.L., he pursued social activism and Hollywood stardom, but his image was stained by accusations of abuse toward women.
content: Jim Brown, the Cleveland Browns fullback who was acclaimed as one of the greatest players in pro football history, and who remained in the public eye as a Hollywood action hero and a civil rights activist, though his name was later tarnished by accusations of violent conduct against women, died on Thursday night at his home in Los Angeles. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Gopnik
title: Ruling Against Warhol Shouldn’t Hurt Artists. But It Might.
description: The Supreme Court decision over Andy Warhol’s use of Lynn Goldsmith’s Prince photograph was decided on the narrow grounds of a licensing issue. But it could still have a chilling effect.
content: The artist Eric Doeringer remembers that his mother was worried, last year, when the Supreme Court took up a case about Andy Warhol’s right to use someone else’s photograph to make his own silk-screened image of the pop star Prince. As one of Warhol’s most committed descendants, Doeringer makes “appropriation art” that most often copies images made by other artists — including, often, by Warhol himself — so his mother wondered what might be in store for her son (now 48) if the court ruled that Warhol’s signature move had been out of line all along.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Naked Stand-Up Comedy: Everything You Imagine, but Oh So Much More
description: Do you wear shoes onstage? What’s it like to bomb while nude? And, ahem, where do you keep your notes? But the shows often sell out.
content: For as long as she can remember, the stand-up comic Carolyn Bergier has had a recurring nightmare where she’s onstage, partly nude. It’s scary, and then she wakes up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Draper
title: A Loud G.O.P. Minority Pledges to Make Trouble on Ukraine Military Aid
description: Hawkish senior Republicans aside, there is evidence to suggest that the anti-Ukraine flank of the party is playing not to the fringe but to the heart of its base.
content: A congressional delegation of five Republicans and two Democrats met with representatives of Ukraine’s Parliament this month in Poland, where the Ukrainians thanked the delegation for American aid and asked for F-16 fighter jets to help in the war against Russia. Three members of the delegation described the meeting as cordial and informative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Golembiewski
title: These Spiders Look Frightening, but They May Be Scaredy-Cats
description: Joro spiders are spreading around the United States and may turn up in New York soon. Recent experiments suggest that they may be shyer than other arachnids.
content: Joro spiders are the size of your palm. They weave webs up to three feet across, and for the past decade, the East Asian arachnids have been spreading throughout the southeastern United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: She Warmed Up to Him After Burning Man
description: Andrew MacRae fell for Kaitlin Green at the annual desert arts festival, but Ms. Green kept her distance until members of their camp met virtually when Covid-19 hit.
content: Andrew Joseph MacRae picked up a last-minute ticket to the Burning Man arts gathering in Black Rock City, Nev., in August 2019, and headed there without teaming up with a camp ahead of time, like most other attendees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samantha Silva
title: My Spectacular Betrayal
description: We had compromised in our marriages, denied parts of ourselves, often felt lonely, but who didn’t? Weren’t we happy enough?
content: I was sitting at DK Donuts in Boise, Idaho, on a dreary November day, talking by phone to my therapist in London, where my husband was, and where I should have been too, if I hadn’t fallen in love with another man and upended our world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Donna Summer’s Bedazzled Closet and Ephemera Will Go Up for Auction
description: Eleven years after her death, the disco legend’s family has combed through her possessions, deciding to sell many of her glittering dresses, manuscripts and paintings.
content: For nearly a decade after Donna Summer’s death in 2012, her home in Nashville remained like a shrine to the Queen of Disco’s decades-long music career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum, Ben Protess and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Trump Ally Could Face Perjury Charge if He Doesn’t Cooperate With D.A.
description: After bringing charges against former President Donald J. Trump, the Manhattan district attorney’s office is once again investigating Allen H. Weisselberg, 75.
content: One of Donald J. Trump’s longtime lieutenants, Allen H. Weisselberg, was recently released from the notorious Rikers Island jail complex after pleading guilty to a tax fraud scheme. Yet Mr. Weisselberg’s legal troubles are far from over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Shrimp Cocktail for Dinner
description: Other weeknight winners: edamame pesto pasta and one-skillet salmon teriyaki.
content: I happen to live near a small but great seafood market, where the fish is impeccably fresh. Their poached shrimp is plump and juicy; the housemade cocktail sauce has just the right zing. I bought them once or twice as a starter for a special meal. But one day I realized that I was holding back: What I really wanted was to eat shrimp cocktail for dinner. And so I did. And it was great.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Why ‘Succession’ Is a Work of Fantasy
description: It imagines a world where elites dictate events.
content: It was interesting, after writing last week’s newsletter on the problems of conservative media, to watch Sunday’s episode of HBO’s “Succession,” in which the show’s lightly fictionalized version of Fox News, run by its somewhat more meaningfully fictionalized version of the Fox-owning Murdoch family, takes center stage for an imagined election night. (There will be some spoilers below, fair warning.) Between the Dominion Voting Systems settlement and the Tucker Carlson firing, we’ve had a lot of real-world Fox drama lately, and the contrast between reality and fiction tells us something interesting about how art depicts our politics — and how the nature of democratic politics can resist successful dramatization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: Britain’s Briefest Prime Minister Gets a Warmer Welcome in Taiwan
description: Liz Truss, the former British prime minister, met Taiwan’s leader, who has sought to push back against China’s efforts to isolate the island democracy.
content: On a controversial trip to Taiwan, Liz Truss, Britain’s prime minister for 44 tempestuous days, met President Tsai Ing-wen on Friday and called for an “economic NATO” to counter Chinese coercion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Averting a Debt Limit Crisis
description: Both parties seem more willing to compromise on the debt limit.
content: For months, the U.S. has been barreling toward a debt limit crisis. Democrats refused to negotiate, and Republicans insisted on a deal stocked with right-wing policy priorities. It was unclear how, or whether, they would avert catastrophe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: A University Fired 2 Employees for Including Their Pronouns in Emails
description: The firings set off a debate at Houghton University, a small Christian institution in western New York, which said its decision was not based only on the pronoun listings.
content: When Raegan Zelaya and Shua Wilmot decided to include their pronouns at the end of their work emails, they thought they were doing a good thing: following what they viewed as an emerging professional standard, and also sending a message of inclusivity at the Christian university where they worked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: ‘White Men Can’t Jump’ Taught a Master Class in Talking Smack
description: Unlike most sports films, the original tale of streetball adversaries, played by Woody Harrelson and Wesley Snipes, wasn’t about winning or losing.
content: “White Men Can’t Jump” was released on March 27, 1992. On the morning of March 28 — according to a wonderful if apocryphal sports legend — Michael Jordan rolled up to the Sunset Ridge Country Club in the suburbs of Chicago, drank around 10 bottles of Coors Light and played two rounds of golf. He had a game that night. Brimming with beer, Jordan posted 44 points, six assists and three steals to help the Bulls beat the visiting Cavaliers 126 to 102.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nia Decaille
title: One Call, and Many Virtual Dates Later, They Found Love
description: Jennifer Kizza and Field Brown felt an immediate connection during their first phone conversation two years ago. “I knew that day, romantic or not, Field was going to be in my life for the rest of my life,” she said.
content: Jennifer Frances Namuli Kizza was feeling tired after work one evening in March 2021. And yet she still kept a scheduled first phone call with Donald Mayfield Brown, whom she had met through a dating app.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Koenig
title: Jeff Bezos’ New Yacht Is Finally Ready to Set Sail
description: Amazon’s founder has been spotted on Koru, a massive schooner with a design that evokes the golden age of sailing in the early 20th century.
content: Just in time for the high season of yachting in the Mediterranean, when multimillion-dollar megayachts descend on ports like Monte Carlo and St. Tropez, Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, has been photographed with his partner Lauren Sánchez on his new boat, Koru, off the coast of Spain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Typing
description: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
content: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration or, tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Jenny Vrentas
title: Jim Brown Piled Up Yards, but Never Wavered an Inch
description: In the fraternity of N.F.L. standouts, Brown was revered for his dominance on the field and for his willingness to walk away on his own terms.
content: A few days before Super Bowl X in 1976, some of the N.F.L.’s biggest stars mingled at a private party at a nightclub in Miami. Chuck Foreman, then a fearsome running back with the Minnesota Vikings, remembered rubbing shoulders with some of the biggest stars of the time at the position, including Walter Payton and O.J. Simpson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Abraham Verghese’s 724-Page Novel Is a Family Affair
description: The physician-author’s new book, “The Covenant of Water,” contains traces of his mother, his cousin and his own medical experience.
content: The New York Times’s review of Abraham Verghese’s debut novel, “Cutting for Stone,” wasn’t negative, per se, but it contained hints of lukewarmness that might have taken some of the air out of its 2009 publication. “Stalwart” and “puzzling” are not the stuff of quotes publishers like to print on paperbacks, nor is damnation by faint praise — for instance, “He is to be admired for his ambition.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Volkswagen Sells Its Russia Operations, Including an Assembly Plant
description: The German automaker, which quit making cars in Russia after the invasion of Ukraine, said it had sold its plant to a local auto dealership chain.
content: Volkswagen has sold its assembly plant and other operations in Russia to a local auto dealership, more than a year after the German carmaker ceased production in the country following the invasion of Ukraine, the company said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: An Ambient Playlist to Create a Bubble of Tranquillity
description: Listen to 8 airy, cumulous songs (keeping in mind that not all ambient music sounds like this).
content: In times when I need to tune out the busy exterior world and tune into my own subconscious, I turn to ambient music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: How a Hip Megachurch Became Entangled in Scandal
description: A new documentary series explores the history of Hillsong, known for its celebrity congregants and fashionable trappings before being struck by a series of scandals.
content: The global megachurch Hillsong was known for its hipster trappings, celebrity congregants and wildly popular worship music in the 2010s, but in recent years it has been more closely tied to a series of scandals, including the firing of its charismatic celebrity pastor, Carl Lentz, for “moral failures.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: How 86 Episodes of ‘The Office’ Solidified Their Connection
description: Samiyyah Ali wasn’t sure how Krystal Ramseur felt about her until Ms. Ramseur made her the equivalent of a comedic mixtape.
content: When Krystal Alyssia Ramseur asked Samiyyah Rasheedah Ali in August 2020 if she wanted to work together to create a virtual improv show about two queer Black women, Ms. Ali was convinced that Ms. Ramseur was coyly asking her out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: ‘No Labels’ Eyes a Third-Party Run in 2024. Democrats Are Alarmed
description: The centrist group is gaining steam — and raising money — in its effort to get a candidate on the 2024 ballot, with Joe Manchin at the top of their list.
content: The bipartisan political group No Labels is stepping up a well-funded effort to field a “unity ticket” for the 2024 presidential race, prompting fierce resistance from even some of its closest allies who fear handing the White House back to Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Athletes With Gun Problems Urge Ja Morant: Learn From Me
description: Gilbert Arenas’s N.B.A. career never recovered after he brought guns into a locker room. Now he’s puzzled by the gun troubles of Morant, the star Memphis Grizzlies guard.
content: Gilbert Arenas figured it was an old video. There was no way, he thought, Ja Morant could have done the same thing so soon after his mea culpa. Not with all that was at stake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang Che
title: China’s Tech Giants Signal the First Steps in a Bumpy Recovery
description: The economy is open again, helping Alibaba, Baidu and Tencent claw back in the first quarter from a miserable 2022, though they are likely to face continuing skepticism from investors.
content: Eight months ago, the future of China’s largest internet companies looked grim. Covid-era lockdowns crushed sales, and Beijing’s harsh tech regulations had spooked even audacious China investors. Shares of Alibaba, Baidu and Tencent dropped to some of their lowest levels in several years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael P. Jeffries
title: When Black Liberation Is the Family Business
description: Santi Elijah Holley’s new book tracks the vision and activism of the Shakurs, from the Black Panthers to Tupac.
content: In 1994, Tupac Shakur gave a stirring interview to MTV about his career and penchant for controversy. Shakur grew up poor and embedded in a Black revolutionary family. He was not always angry, but he insisted Black rage was logical: America exploited and persecuted Black people, extracting talented survivors like him from the ghetto, and condemning those left behind to violence and early death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Nereim
title: Zelensky Urges Arab Leaders Not to ‘Turn a Blind Eye’ to Russian Aggression
description: Addressing an Arab League summit in Saudi Arabia, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine urged Arab nations to stand with him against Russia and called out their reluctance to take sides in the war.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine implored Arab leaders meeting in Saudi Arabia on Friday not to bend to Russian influence, as he continued a diplomatic tour to build international support ahead of a widely anticipated Ukrainian counteroffensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Bernstein
title: Cool Tribal Tattoo. Is It From the ’90s?
description: The style, once dismissed for being culturally appropriative and meathead-y, is back.
content: Sometimes, a customer walks into Name Brand Tattoo on North Main Street and asks Julian Bast to design a tattoo just like the ones on his Instagram account. They use words like “psychedelic,” “abstract” and “swirly.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Bill Perkins, Defender of His Harlem Constituents, Dies at 74
description: As a councilman and state senator, he fought for higher wages, health care, gay rights and sought justice for the Central Park Five.
content: Bill Perkins, who for 24 years as a legislator from Harlem championed his community — by, among other things, challenging Donald J. Trump’s aggressive demand for the death penalty when five teenagers, who were later exonerated, were arrested in connection with a rape in Central Park in 1989 — died on Tuesday  at his home in Manhattan. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Jamaal Bowman Finds His Voice. Some Republicans Don’t Like the Sound.
description: The Democratic congressman has made a habit of brashly confronting Republicans like Marjorie Taylor Greene, often in public displays meant to attract attention.
content: Many of his colleagues had already left for the night, but as Representative Jamaal Bowman, Democrat of New York, stepped out onto the Capitol steps on Wednesday, he had business left to do: heckling Republicans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Sotheby’s Provenance Disputed in Claim by Heirs for Art Lost in Nazi Era
description: The relatives of a Jewish gallery owner who left a Tiepolo painting behind when he fled Austria say the auction house posted a misleading history of the work during a 2019 sale.
content: In 2019, Sotheby’s sold a work by Giovanni Battista Tiepolo, the master painter, that was left behind in Austria when a Jewish gallery owner fled the Nazis in 1938. Sotheby’s says that at the time of the sale it didn’t know that history, and so the auction catalog only mentioned that the work came from a “distinguished private collection” and had once been in the possession of the Galerie Wolfgang Böhler in Bensheim, Germany.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Jean Twenge
description: The May 19, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Jean Twenge. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: Brittney Griner Is Creating a New Normal, for Herself and the W.N.B.A.
description: Griner returns to basketball after her detention in Russia with a bigger platform and a desire to reshape women’s sports.
content: PHOENIX — Brittney Griner embarked on a four-day itinerary that would disrupt anyone’s circadian rhythm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Schaitkin
title: What Makes a Woman Commit Violence?
description: In Ivy Pochoda’s new thriller, “Sing Her Down,” two recently released prison inmates migrate from Arizona to Los Angeles, leaving a string of grisly scenes in their wake.
content: “You won’t believe what women can do,” a female prisoner named Kace says at the start of Ivy Pochoda’s latest thriller, “Sing Her Down” — and the declaration could serve as the novel’s credo. This is a story about violence by women, against them and within them. It is, specifically, the tale of Florence “Florida” Baum and Diana Diosmary “Dios” Sandoval. From the jump, we’re told that their drama will end in a violent showdown. The novel watches as they move inexorably toward it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo and Gaia Pianigiani
title: After Earthquakes and Drought, Floods Devastate Northern Italy
description: At least 14 people died and thousands were left homeless after some areas received half their annual rainfall in 36 hours in a region that had only recently finished rebuilding after a 2012 earthquake.
content: Eleven years ago this month, back-to-back earthquakes struck the northern Italian region of Emilia-Romagna, which this week was devastated by another disaster: Widespread flooding that has caused at least 14 deaths and left thousands more homeless.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Gay
title: The Wrong Way to Cut New York City’s Budget
description: Mayor Eric Adams appears to be making some strange choices.
content: After a decade-long spending spree and a devastating pandemic, New York City is now staring at three years of huge budget deficits, beginning with at least $4.2 billion in the year that starts in July 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: We Want to Hear From Australia Letter Readers
description: What should we be covering? Are there stories that the rest of the world should know about? Let us know.
content: The Australia Letter recently celebrated its sixth birthday. Over more than 300 issues, we’ve shared the back stories to our reporting trips, offered local recommendations and served up slices of life down under.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Disney Inflicts a Blow to DeSantis Ahead of His Presidential Run
description: The entertainment giant’s move to cancel a major office project stung the Florida governor just days before he is expected to officially enter the 2024 race.
content: After months of anticipation, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida is expected to formally declare his candidacy for president next week, officially taking on Donald Trump for the Republican nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Police in Australia Use Stun Gun on 95-Year-Old Woman
description: She was holding a knife, but weighs 95 pounds and uses a walker. The episode, which took place in a care facility, prompted outrage, questions and a police investigation.
content: The Australian police are investigating why an experienced officer used a Taser on a 95-year-old woman who had approached him “at a slow pace” while holding a steak knife.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Hurubie Meko
title: At Harlem Funeral for Jordan Neely, an Outpouring of Grief
description: Hundreds gathered to mourn Mr. Neely, who was choked to death earlier this month on the subway, including the Rev. Al Sharpton, who eulogized him.
content: Jordan Neely spent the last few weeks of his life riding the subways of New York, hungry, desperate and alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jackie Frere
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: The Rev. Timothy Keller, Pioneering Manhattan Evangelist, Dies at 72
description: Shunning fire and brimstone, he became a best-selling author and founded Redeemer Presbyterian Church, which drew young New Yorkers.
content: The Rev. Timothy J. Keller, a best-selling author and theorist of Christianity who performed a modern miracle of his own — establishing a theologically orthodox church in Manhattan that attracted thousands of young professional followers — died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Requiem for the 7 Dead Horses of Kentucky Derby Week
description: When seven thoroughbreds died at Churchill Downs, it was significant news, but little was said about the individual horses. Here are their stories, beginning with a $13,000 colt called Snowball.
content: Her voice catches and tears threaten to follow, but Randy Gootzeit wants you to know about how a strapping gray colt nicknamed Snowball brought a couple of horse lovers back to the track, and how they got their hearts broken.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Jimmy Buffett, Hospitalized After Bahamas Trip, Cancels Show
description: The 76-year-old performer canceled a Saturday performance in Charleston, S.C., for unspecified health reasons. He had resumed touring this year after canceling a series of shows in October.
content: Jimmy Buffett, the singer-songwriter who has built a lucrative lifestyle empire on the basis of beach-bum anthems like “Margaritaville” and “It’s 5 O’Clock Somewhere,” canceled a show scheduled for Saturday in Charleston, S.C., after he was hospitalized for an unspecified illness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Negotiations over the U.S. debt limit.
content: For months, the U.S. has thundered toward a debt limit crisis. Democrats refused to negotiate, and Republicans insisted on a deal stocked with right-wing policy priorities. More recently, President Biden has agreed to have his staff meet directly with Speaker Kevin McCarthy’s aides, and the chances of getting a deal to increase the borrowing limit now seem higher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Why Is George Santos Still in Office?
description: Deceiving voters undermines public faith in Congress.
content: George Santos is far from the first member of Congress to be indicted while in office. Both chambers and both parties have endured their share of scandals. In 2005, for instance, F.B.I. agents discovered $90,000 hidden in the freezer of Representative William Jefferson, who was under investigation for bribery. He refused to step down, wound up losing his seat in the 2008 election, and was later sentenced to 13 years in prison. James Traficant was expelled from Congress in 2002 after being convicted of bribery and racketeering. Bob Ney resigned in 2006 because of his involvement in a federal bribery scandal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean Keenan
title: Body Cameras Can Be a Powerful Tool. But Not All Police Forces Wear Them.
description: Officers in Georgia killed an activist who they say shot first. But a lack of video footage has inflamed the controversy over the death.
content: When the Georgia authorities attempted to clear protesters from forested property near Atlanta in January, to make way for the construction of a $90 million police and fire training facility, a confrontation with a group of activists who deride the project as “Cop City” led to a barrage of gunfire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Expect Interest Rates on Federal Student Loans to Rise
description: Rates for undergraduate loans could top 5 percent next school year, adding pressure on families already struggling to pay for college.
content: Interest rates on new federal student loans are expected to exceed 5 percent for the first time in five years, adding to the pressure on families already struggling to pay for college.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson
title: A.I.-Generated Content Discovered on News Sites, Content Farms and Product Reviews
description: The findings in two new reports raise fresh concerns over how artificial intelligence may transform the misinformation landscape online.
content: Dozens of fringe news websites, content farms and fake reviewers are using artificial intelligence to create inauthentic content online, according to two reports released on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland
title: James Gorman, Morgan Stanley’s Long-Serving C.E.O., Will Step Down Within a Year
description: A successor to Mr. Gorman has not been identified, but he said there were three internal candidates.
content: James Gorman, Morgan Stanley’s chief executive, told a shareholder meeting on Friday that he planned to step down from the bank’s top job “at some point in the next 12 months,” bringing to a close the tenure of one of the longest-serving bank chiefs on Wall Street. He did not identify a successor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: Nebraska Votes to Restrict Abortion and Transgender Care for Minors
description: After weeks of acrimonious debate, Republicans put the two fraught issues into a single bill, which the governor has said he will sign.
content: Nebraska lawmakers voted on Friday to restrict access to abortion and medical care for transgender youth, after weeks of vociferous debate on two issues that have divided state legislators across the country this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alec Nevala-Lee
title: The Martian Chronicles
description: In Matthew Shindell’s “For the Love of Mars,” perceptions of the planet reflect the changing culture of Earth.
content: When we trace it back to its etymological origins, a planet is, literally, a wanderer — a point of light that strays. Usually, it moves in the same direction as the stars, but sometimes it halts and reverses course. This retrograde motion, which occurs when Earth overtakes a planet in its orbit, is hard to square with a geocentric model of the universe, but it was full of meaning for cultures that looked to the heavens for messages. The systems of knowledge that slowly evolved into the natural sciences arose from the study of omens, abundantly provided by the planets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: The Fast, the Furious and All of the Feuds
description: As “Fast X” races into theaters, here’s a look at the conflicts — star vs. star, star vs. director and more — that have kept this franchise in high gear.
content: Over the course of more than 20 years of the “Fast and Furious” — the 10th in the franchise, “Fast X,” arrives this weekend — battles have been fought, villains have been overcome, friends have become foes and lovers have been reunited. (There was even a case of alignment-altering amnesia.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Will ‘Superfood Powders’ Actually Make You Healthier?
description: These once-daily supplements claim to boost energy, nourish your gut, support your immune system and more. But health experts aren’t convinced.
content: You’ve probably noticed ads for these “superfood powders” scattered across social media or on your favorite podcast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Polgreen
title: Ron DeSantis Knows That the Best Place to Humiliate People Is in the Bathroom
description: Restrooms have long been porcelain crucibles for our fears and anxieties, which is why the right knows they are good sites for humiliating trans people.
content: A few years ago, I attended an advertising conference in the South of France. I was staying at a glitzy hotel on a glittering boulevard along the Côte d’Azur. I was in business attire, a navy pantsuit. On my way to a meeting, I ducked into the women’s bathroom off the lobby. Then I heard heavy footsteps and a breathless voice saying, in French, “There’s a man in the bathroom!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Pays Silent Tribute to Victims of Hiroshima Bomb
description: The president joined other leaders in laying wreaths at a memorial to the first wartime use of a nuclear weapon, amid growing fears that one could be used again.
content: President Biden was 2 years old when the nuclear era opened with a blast of devastation unlike any the world had ever seen. Seventy-eight years later, he came on Friday to ground zero of the first atomic bomb used in warfare to pay tribute to the dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fu
title: 1 in 5 Young Chinese Is Jobless, and Millions More Are About to Graduate
description: The youth unemployment rate, which spiked during the pandemic, reached a record high this week, showing the perils of China’s uneven economic recovery.
content: Shu Xiang, 21, started looking for a job in February and still has had no luck. A financial management major at a college in Chengdu, China, Ms. Shu said she had received five responses to about 100 applications. Graduation is in a few weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Two Theories for Beating Trump in the Primary
description: A successful campaign will probably need the traits of both Trumpism and an alternative to Trumpism.
content: There are two basic theories for how Donald J. Trump might be defeated in a Republican primary. It’s possible that neither, both or some combination of the two can actually work in practice. But by considering them in depth, it becomes easier to think about and judge the various efforts to beat him — and why so many haven’t pulled it off.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Essential Neil Gaiman and A.I. Book Freakout
description: Where to start with one of today’s most prolific and beloved fantasy writers, and the robot who wrote a murder mystery.
content: From the cult comic book series “The Sandman” to the giddy novel “Good Omens” (co-written with his friend Terry Pratchett) to the horror-tinged children’s story “Coraline” and beyond, the fantasy writer Neil Gaiman is so inventive and so prolific that you’ve probably stumbled across his influential work without even realizing it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: What the Markets Are Saying About the Risk of a Debt Default
description: The odds of a U.S. default are low, but the consequences could be dire. Our columnist explains how financial markets are assessing the risks.
content: The headlines have been warning for weeks about a possible debt default by the United States. Negotiations have become contentious, with a deadline that could come as soon as June 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: A ‘Canadian Armageddon’ Sets Parts of Western Canada on Fire
description: Wildfires raging in Alberta and British Columbia have created a sense of panic and fear, and forced thousands of residents to evacuate from their homes.
content: As acrid smoke filled the air, turning the sky around her sleepy hometown, Fox Creek, Alberta, a garish blood orange, Nicole Clarke said she felt a sense of terror.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Wildman
title: My Daughter’s Future Was Taken From Her, and From Us
description: On the particular grief of losing an adolescent child.
content: In late 2008, toward the end of my pregnancy with Orli, I interviewed the actor Harvey Fierstein, then starring in “Hairspray.” As I made my way through the crowd backstage at the Neil Simon Theater, past cast members and stage managers, hangers-on and well-wishers, Mr. Fierstein caught a glimpse of my belly. “Make way!” he barked, raspily. “This woman is carrying the hopes and dreams of her entire family!” Everyone laughed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison and Niraj Chokshi
title: JetBlue-American Partnership Struck Down by Federal Judge
description: An alliance begun in 2021 at four airports in the New York area and Boston allowed the airlines to sell tickets on each other’s flights and share revenue.
content: A federal judge halted a partnership between American Airlines and JetBlue Airways at airports in New York and Boston, writing in a ruling on Friday that the alliance would hurt competition and raise fares.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Small Earthquake Hits Just North of New York City
description: The earthquake, which struck just before 2 a.m., had a preliminary magnitude of 2.2 and was centered about 20 miles north of the city.
content: A minor earthquake rumbled through parts of Westchester County in New York early on Friday, with tremors reportedly felt in New York City and towns in northern New Jersey. There were no immediate reports of damage or injuries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Amazon Is Everywhere. That’s What Makes It So Vulnerable.
description: For years, the e-commerce giant could shield its vast archipelago of warehouses against disruptions from workers. Then it got even bigger.
content: Is there a more familiar sign of corporate dominance than the Amazon delivery van?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Founding Member of This Church Was Enslaved by Its First Pastor
description: When the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church learned of its ties to slavery, it named its boardroom after Betsey Jackson, one of its 26 original members in 1808.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at how a Manhattan church is reckoning with the discovery that one of its founding members was an enslaved woman. We’ll also find out about a proposed change in the way restaurants dispose of trash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Zach Montague
title: D.C. Police Lieutenant Charged With Leaking Information to Proud Boys Leader
description: Federal prosecutors accused the veteran officer of providing law-enforcement information to Enrique Tarrio, who was head of the far-right group.
content: Federal prosecutors unsealed charges on Friday against a veteran police officer in Washington, accusing him of obstructing justice by leaking law enforcement information to Enrique Tarrio, the former leader of the Proud Boys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: 15 Hours on the Job With a Bagel Roller
description: A team of five reporters and video producers spent a day shadowing Celestino García for the Cooking team’s “On the Job” YouTube series.
content: It’s dark. It’s 39 degrees outside. And it’s 2:40 a.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekita Rivas
title: A Tinder Match Leads to Wanderlust and a Weed Wedding
description: After hitting it off on a dating app, Keith Jefferson and Constance Ejismekwu became travel partners, taking back-to-back trips until the pandemic.
content: After Keith Quinntarus Jefferson and Constance Chinyere Ejismekwu matched on Tinder in December 2018, it didn’t take long for them to realize they had something special. They initially communicated via FaceTime on New Year’s Eve and went on their first date the next day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: The Decision After an Affair
description: “From spring to summer, we debated whether to tell our spouses, the harm we would cause by leaving them, the happiness we might miss if we didn’t.”
content: In this week’s Modern Love essay, “My Spectacular Betrayal,” Samantha Silva describes her extramarital affair and her decision to start a new life despite the judgments of others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: 8-Year-Old Migrant Died After a Week in U.S. Detention
description: The death this week is at the center of concerns about the government’s policy of detaining children for any period of time, often in crowded settings.
content: An 8-year-old girl who died while in U.S. border custody on Wednesday had been detained for a week — more than twice the amount of time the government generally aims to hold migrants, particularly children, according to two people familiar with the situation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hari Kumar and Sameer Yasir
title: Cheetah Deaths in India Mar Reintroduction Efforts
description: The animals had been extinct for more than 70 years in the country, which has just begun a program that brought 20 cheetahs from Africa to a wildlife sanctuary.
content: For centuries, cheetahs roamed vast swaths of India and prowled among lions, tigers and leopards. They were declared extinct in 1952 after decades of hunting by princely rulers and British colonizers, shrinking habitats and vanishing prey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Mooj Zadie, Will Reid, Mike Benoist, Marion Lozano, Daniel Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Diane Wong, Rowan Niemisto, Brad Fisher and Chris Wood
title: When the Culture Wars Came for NASA
description: The naming of the James Webb telescope kindled an unexpected firestorm in the agency and across the wider scientific community.
content: The James Webb Space Telescope, the most powerful ever made, has revolutionized the way we see the universe. The name was chosen for James E. Webb, a NASA administrator during the 1960s. But when doubts about his background emerged, the telescope’s name turned into a fight over homophobia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: If You Care About Book Bans, You Should Be Following This Lawsuit
description: A constitutional challenge to Florida’s book-restricting frenzy.
content: Lindsay Durtschi, a member of the P.T.A. in bright-red Escambia County, Fla., knows that coming out as a public face in the fight against book banning could make her life difficult, but she’s made peace with it. “I don’t want my business to suffer,” the optometrist and mother of elementary school-age girls told me. “I don’t want my kids to be bullied.” She worries her family could be threatened. “But if that’s what ends up happening, then I’ll tell everybody about it. I’m not one to keep my mouth shut.”

title: ‘The Fears’ Review: Group Therapy Was Never More Triggering
description: For the fragile souls in this new play, presented by Steven Soderbergh, a Buddhist group that once offered them solace loses its way.
content: “This is the weather … and we’re just in it,” says Maia, the facilitator of a Buddhist trauma group at the center of Emma Sheanshang’s new play, “The Fears.” She’s talking about the mood in the room — a small, underwhelming one with mismatched office chairs set around a low wooden table — where she and six others regularly meet to talk through storms of rage, sorrow and panic. Or at least try to: interpersonal conflicts, clashing neuroses and a falling domino effect of triggers cause more breakdowns than breakthroughs, until even the group’s philosophical foundation starts to fall apart.

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Rachel Cohn, Jen Poyant, Alyssa Moxley, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano, Sophia Lanman and Rowan Niemisto
title: Mr. Altman Goes to Washington, and Casey Goes on This American Life

content: In a congressional hearing this week, OpenAI’s chief executive, Sam Altman, appeared to be on the same page as lawmakers: It’s time to regulate A.I. But like so many other proposals to regulate tech, will it actually happen? The Times’s technology reporter Cecilia Kang helps us understand whether Congress will actually act, and what that could look like.

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Husband Flies First Class and Puts Me in Coach. Is That Fair?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on who deserves what in a marriage.
content: My husband loves to travel and always either pays for, or gets an upgrade into, the first-class cabin. When we travel together with our children, he buys himself a ticket in first class and puts us in economy or economy plus. He even did this recently on an overnight flight to Paris. He justifies flying alone in first class because of the cost, and the fact that our kids (12 and 16) might feel alone if I were to travel in first with him and leave them in the rear cabin. I feel that this is unfair.

The machine and its contents were impounded, and two passengers and the pilot were sent on by rail after interrogation.
